text:
hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with barbarian beef that's right

i've always wanted to try to cook a
large hunk of meat right on the coals

with no grill or any other modern
conveniences or equipment except maybe a

sheet pan and some tongs and possibly a
meat thermometer but anyway the point is

i wanted to try to cook a nice slab of
beef right on the coals and possibly

sort of the same way our savage
ancestors did and what follows is that

almost totally successful experiment and
first up we're going to need a nice

thick piece of beef which was a nice
thick piece of top round sold as a

London broil that I plundered from a
local butcher well not so much plundered

but it was on sale and what we're gonna
do is salt both sides very generously

and I kind of debated with myself
whether I should put some other spices

and herbs on this but since my plan was
for this to go right on the hot coals

I was afraid those my singe and burn and
tastes weird so I decided to just stick

with salt and yes it is true top round
is not the most tender beef but it is

pretty cheap and since I didn't know how
this was gonna come out I didn't really

want to take a chance ruining a nice
thick piece of rib eye or even top

sirloin which of course in hindsight I
wish I had but anyway we're gonna go

ahead and season that up and we'll just
let that sit out at room temp for about

a half hour another that maybe flipping
it over halfway through we really don't

have to do anything else to the meat but
what we do need to do is get our coals

going and for this technique only one
type of charcoal is gonna work and

that's an all-natural 100% hardwood and
natural lump charcoal okay we don't want

to use any kind of briquettes here that
have additives and binders okay we want

pure good old-fashioned charcoal and in
case you're keeping score at home this

is Mesquite
and what we'll need to do before we

place our meat on is let this burn down
until the point where we have beautiful

ashy white glowing red coals which we
might have to arrange a little bit so we

have a nice flat surface and then what
we'll do once we think our turkle's burn

long enough and it looks something like
this is go ahead and place down our meat

and it might just be my ancient
barbarian DNA talking but even though

this kind of looked wrong it felt so
right but anyway place the meat down and

I decided to move a couple coals to this
right side

since I wasn't sure that was getting
enough heat and since I'd never tried

this before I didn't really have a game
plan except I decided to give each side

about four minutes or so and then just
figure it out from there so that's what

I did I gave that first side about four
minutes and flipped it over and I'm not

gonna lie it didn't look that good all
right there was some weird spotting and

I was a little bit concerned it wasn't
gonna cook evenly but then I remembered

how cheap this piece of meat was and
then if it didn't work I'll just chop it

up and make soup but anyway I gave that
second side about four minutes before

flipping it over again and even though
it still looked a little bit weird the

appearance was getting a little better
and my instincts told me that because of

the intense heat from those coals that
we were gonna have a lot of carryover

Heat meaning this is gonna keep cooking
once you pull it off because the surface

is so so hot
so I decided to pull mine off at about

120 internal temp figuring that would
give me a perfect medium-rare but as

you'll see that didn't quite work out
and we went a little bit over that but

anyway after a total of about five or
six minutes per side I went ahead and

pulled it off and even though it looked
kind of weird as it was cooking as soon

as I brought this inside and the meat
juices started to come to the surface it

started to look a lot better and it
pretty much looked like something that

came off a charcoal grill so I was very
anxious to slice it and have a taste but

I knew I should let it rest a little bit
so I set that aside and move down to

quickly making a very appropriate and
very rustic sauce so I decided to take

some garlic and some hot chili peppers
and a little bit of rosemary and a nice

big pinch of salt and I went ahead and
smashed that into a paste using this

mortar which was of course the barbarian
equivalent of a food processor and of

course takes a lot more time and effort
and by the time I finish this I was

grown and like Conan but totally worth
it anyway once we have everything

crushed nice and small we'll go ahead
and splash in some fermented wine which

we call these days vinegar as well as a
little splash of olive oil and we will

give that a mix and that's it our
extremely primitive but what turned out

to be an amazingly delicious sauce is
done and by now my barbarian beef had

cooled down and was ready to slice and
as soon as I cut those first few slices

I realized there was a lot more
carryover heat than I had anticipated

and this was closer to medium
while than it was the medium-rare so

next time I'll probably pull it off a
little sooner but despite our doneness

issues the taste was absolutely amazing
okay there was absolutely no unpleasant

burned or charred flavor all right it
really did taste like something that

would come off a regular grill but it
actually had a little deeper a little

more pronounced smokiness that I really
really liked so for me this was

somewhere between smoked beef and
grilled beef

all right sort of like the smokiness you
get with a pastrami hey are you thinking

what I'm thinking but anyway that's
another video so I went ahead and sliced

up some more nice and thin right the
cheaper and tougher your beef the

thinner the slice and since we cooked
the beef barbarian style I decided to

serve a barbarian style right on the
board and just went ahead and spooned

that savage sauce over the top and
finished up with a little bit of fresh

rosemary and even though that plain
piece of beef really was delicious

when you combine that smoky meat with
this spicy acidic garlicky Irby sauce it

was whatever the barbarian word for
vantastic was which I believe was mmm

and of course if I'd known it was going
to come out this good I would have used

a better cut of beef but this top round
as long as you slice it pretty thin is

not bad it would make a beautiful
beautiful sandwich open-faced or

otherwise and while I really do think
our smash salsa was perfect with this

there are so many other things that
could work here like a nice aioli or

chimichurri or even and sort of
obviously a barbecue sauce so how you

serve this is going to be up to you
I mean you are after all the savage of

how best to ravage but anyway that's it
what I'm calling barbarian beef I've

never actually done one of those DNA
tests so I'm not sure if I actually have

any barbarian genes but is anyone that
seen my table manners could tell you is

definitely a possibility but regardless
I found that cooking meat directly on

the coals was not only fun but strangely
satisfying and most importantly very

delicious so whether you're trying to
get in touch with your inner barbarian

or just want to freak out your friends
at the next cookout I really do hope you

give this unusual but very effective
technique a try soon so head over to

food wishes comm for all the ingredient
amounts and more info as usual and as
always enjoy
you
